tit.cmt: 「五十猛神」は「いそたけるのかみ」と読むことも多いかと思いますが、ここでは原文での読みの指定にあわせ「いそたける」としております。

sen.j: 五十猛神（イソタケル）は、日本神話に登場する神 (神道)。
sen.e: Isotakeru, written as 五十猛神 in Japanese, is a god (in Shinto) appearing in Japanese mythology.
Isotakeru, written as 五十猛神 in Japanese, is a Shinto god appearing in Japanese mythology.
Isotakeru is a Shinto god appearing in Japanese mythology.
sen.cmt: written as 五十猛神 in Japanese→削除

sen.j: 「イタケル」とも読まれる。
sen.e: His name is also pronounced as Itakeru.
His name is also pronounced as Itakeru.
His name is also pronounced as Itakeru.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』『先代旧事本紀』に登場するが、『古事記』に登場する大屋毘古神（オホヤビコ）と同一神とされる。
sen.e: This god appears in the "Nihonshoki" (the Chronicles of Japan) and the "Sendai Kujihongi" (the Ancient Japanese History), and he is thought to be the same god as Oyabiko, who appears in the "Kojiki" (the Records of Ancient Matters).

This god appears in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and the "Sendai Kujihongi" (Ancient Japanese History), and he is thought to be the same god as Oyabiko, who appears in the "Kojiki" (the Records of Ancient Matters).

This god appears in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and the "Sendai Kujihongi" (Ancient Japanese History), and he is thought to be the same god as Oyabiko, who appears in the "Kojiki" (the Records of Ancient Matters).

sen.j: 素戔嗚尊（スサノオ）の子で、大屋都比賣神・抓津姫神は妹。
sen.e: He is a child of Susanoo (a god of sea and storms in Japanese mythology), and Oyatsuhime (a goddess in Japanese mythology) and Tsumatsuhime (a goddess in Japanese mythology) are his younger sisters.
He is a child of Susanoo (a god of sea and storms), and his younger sisters are the goddesses Oyatsuhime and Tsumatsuhime.
He is a child of Susanoo (a god of sea and storms), and his younger sisters are the goddesses Oyatsuhime and Tsumatsuhime.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』、『先代旧事本紀』の記述から、五十猛神は林業の神として信仰されている。
sen.e: According to the descriptions in the "Nihonshoki" and the "Sendai Kuji Hongi," Isotakeru is worshipped as a god of forestry.
According to the descriptions in the "Nihonshoki" and the "Sendai Kuji Hongi," Isotakeru is worshipped as a god of forestry.
According to the descriptions in the "Nihonshoki" and the "Sendai Kujihongi," Isotakeru is worshipped as a god of forestry.

sen.j: 紀伊は古来より林業の盛んな地であったので、それらの人々が信仰していた神と考えられる。
sen.e: Since Kii Province had been a prosperous region for forestry since the ancient times, it is considered this god was worshipped by people in that industry.
Kii Province had been an important region for forestry since ancient times and it is believed that Isotakeru was worshipped by people in that industry.
Kii Province had been an important region for forestry since ancient times and it is believed that Isotakeru was worshipped by people in that industry.

sen.j: 紀伊国（かつては「木の国」と言った）に祀られているとの記述と『先代旧事本紀』分注に「亦云 大屋彦神」とあることから、『古事記』で大国主がその元に逃げ込んだ木国の大屋毘古神と同一神とされる。
sen.e: Since the description says this god is enshrined in Kii Province (which used to be called 'Ki no Kuni,' which literally means a country of trees) and also an annotation in the "Sendai Kujihongi" says '亦云 大屋彦神' (which means 'it is also called Oyahiko'), he is regarded as the same god as Oyabiko in Ki no Kuni, who was asked his help by Okuninushi (the chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region) in the "Kojiki."

From the fact that the description says he is enshrined in Kii Province (formerly called 'Ki no Kuni,' which literally means 'country of trees') and also from an annotation in the "Sendai Kujihongi" which says 'he is also called Oyahiko', Isotakeru is regarded as the same god as Oyabiko of Ki no Kuni, who gave refuge to Okuninushi (the chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu) in the "Kojiki."
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity, brevity - deleted kanji and shortened explanation of Okuninushi
sen.e: From the fact that the description says he is enshrined in Kii Province (formerly called 'Ki no Kuni,' which literally means 'country of trees') and also from an annotation in the "Sendai Kujihongi" which says 'he is also called Oyahiko', Isotakeru is regarded as the same god as Oyabiko of Ki no Kuni, who gave refuge to Okuninushi (the chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu) in the "Kojiki."

sen.j: イザナギ・イザナミの子である大屋毘古神（禍津日神と同一神とされる）とは別神であるが、同一神とされることもある。
sen.e: He is a different god from Kataku Rokushin (a group of six deities who protect a house), who is a child of Izanagi (a god in Japanese mythology) and Izanami (a goddess in Japanese mythology) and is regarded as the same god as Magatsuhi no Kami (a god of disorder in Japanese mythology), but some people think they are the same god.
sen.cmt: 「家宅六神」は六柱の神の総称であり、文脈上適当ではありませんが、原文通りに翻訳しております。なお原文「家宅六神」部分はウィキペディア上では「大屋毘古神」と表記されており、そのリンク先が「家宅六神」となっているためにこのような原文表記になったと思われます。
sen.e: He is thought by some to be one of the six Kataku Rokushin deities of protecting houses (the one identified with the god of disorder, Magatsuhi no Kami) who were the children of Izanagi and Izanami (the god and goddess who created the Japanese islands), but he is in fact a different deity.
sen.cmt: *Revised for clarity - though it makes the sentence pretty cluttered trying to explain all the kami
sen.e: He is thought by some to be Oyabiko no kami (the one identified with the god of disorder, Magatsuhi no Kami) who was the children of Izanagi and Izanami (the god and goddess who created the Japanese islands), but he is in fact a different deity.
sen.cmt: Ｅ欄のとおり、「家宅六神」はウェブで確認したところ「大屋毘古神」となっているので、原文も訳文もそう訂正しました。Were→was

sen.j: 『日本書紀』 卷第一 で『ヤマタノオロチ退治が述べられている第八段第四の一書において以下のように書かれている。
sen.e: In the first volume of the "Nihonshoki," the fourth issho (a variant version) describing the defeat of Yamatanoorochi (eight-forked-snake) in the eighth section says as follows.
In the first volume of the "Nihonshoki," the fourth issho (addendum) of the the eighth section, which describes the defeat of Yamatanoorochi (the Eight-Forked Serpent), says as follows.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - changed "a variant version" to "addendum"
sen.e: In the first volume of the "Nihonshoki," the fourth issho (addendum) of the the eighth section, which describes the defeat of Yamatanoorochi (the Eight-Forked Serpent), says as follows.

sen.j: 一書曰
sen.e: The issho says as follows.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処以下、括弧内は現代語訳です。なお日本書紀の現代語訳は「日本書紀 全現代語訳（講談社学術文庫）」を参考といたしました。「一書にいう。」
sen.e: The issho says as follows.
The issho says as follows.

sen.j: 素戔嗚尊所行無状
sen.e: Susanoo had bad behavior.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「素戔嗚尊の行いがひどかった。」
sen.e: Susanoo behaved wickedly.
Susanoo behaved wickedly.

sen.j: 故諸神 科以千座置戸 而遂逐之
sen.e: Accordingly the gods sentenced him to the chikura no okido (the severest punishment of property confiscation) and banished him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「そこで神々が、千座の置戸の罪を科せられて追放された。」
sen.e: Accordingly the gods punished him by confiscating his property and banished him.
Accordingly the gods punished him by confiscating his property and banished him.

sen.j: 是時 素戔嗚尊 帥其子五十猛神 降到於新羅國 居曾尸茂梨之處
sen.e: Susanoo then descended to the country called Silla with his child named Isotakeru no Kami, and went to a place called Soshimori.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「このとき素戔嗚尊は、その子五十猛神をひきいて、新羅の国に降りられて、曾尸茂梨のところにおいでになった。」参考図書の記述にしたがい、ここでは「五十猛神」を「いそたけるのかみ」と読んでおります。
sen.e: Susanoo then descended to the country called Silla (on the Korean Peninsula) with his child named Isotakeru no Kami, and went to a place called Soshimori.
Susanoo then descended to the country called Silla (on the Korean Peninsula) with his child named Isotakeru no Kami, and went to a place called Soshimori.

sen.j: 乃興言曰 此地吾不欲居
sen.e: In that place he complained 'I do not want to stay here.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「そこで不服の言葉をいわれて、「この地には私は居たくないのだ」と。」
sen.e: In that place he complained, saying 'I do not want to stay here.'
In that place he complained, saying 'I do not want to stay here.'

sen.j: 遂以埴土作舟 乘之東渡 到出雲國簸川上所在 鳥上之峯
sen.e: Thus he made a boat from clay and traveled to the east by that boat, and then he reached Mt. Torikami located at the upper reaches of Hi-kawa River in Izumo Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「ついに土で舟を造り、それに乗って東の方に渡り、出雲の国の簸の川の上流にある、鳥上の山についた。」
sen.e: Thus he made a boat from clay and used it to travel to the east, and then he reached Mt. Torikami located at the upper reaches of Hi-kawa River in Izumo Province.
Thus he made a boat from clay and used it to travel to the east, and then he reached Mt. Torikami located at the upper reaches of Hi-kawa River in Izumo Province.

sen.j: 時彼處有呑人大蛇
sen.e: Incidentally, there was a monster serpent which eats human beings in that place.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「ときにそこに人を呑む大蛇がいた。」
sen.e: In that place, there was a man-eating monster serpent.
In that place, there was a man-eating monster serpent.

sen.j: 素戔嗚尊 乃以天蝿斫之劔 斬彼大蛇
sen.e: Susanoo defeated that serpent with a sword called Amanoha-hakiri no Tsurugi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「素戔嗚尊は天蝿斫剣（あまのははきりのつるぎ）をもって、その大蛇を斬られた。」
sen.e: Susanoo defeated the serpent with a sword called Amanoha-hakiri no Tsurugi.
Susanoo defeated the serpent with a sword called Amanoha-hakiri no Tsurugi.

sen.j: 時斬蛇尾而刃缺
sen.e: The sword chipped after he cut the serpent's tail.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「ときに蛇の尾を斬って刃が欠けた。」
sen.e: The sword chipped as he cut the serpent's tail.
The sword chipped as he cut the serpent's tail.

sen.j: 即擘而視之 尾中有一神劔
sen.e: He cut up that part to see the inside of the tail, and found a mysterious sword there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「そこで割いてごらんになると、尾の中に一つの不思議な剣があった。」
sen.e: He cut up the tail to see inside it, and found a mysterious sword there.
He cut up the tail to see inside it, and found a mysterious sword there.

sen.j: 素戔嗚尊曰 此不可以吾私用也
sen.e: Susanoo said 'This cannot pass into my possession.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「素戔嗚尊がいわれるのに、「これは私の物とすることはできない」と。」
sen.e: Susanoo said, 'This cannot pass into my possession.'
Susanoo said, 'This cannot pass into my possession.'

sen.j: 乃遺五世孫天之葺根神 上奉於天
sen.e: Therefore he sent Amanohukine no Kami (a god in Japanese mythology), who was a descendant after five generations from Susanoo, to offer it to heaven.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「そこで五代の孫である天之葺根神（あまのふきねのかみ）を遣わして、天に奉られた。」
sen.e: Therefore he sent Amanohukine no Kami, who was a fifth-generation descendant of Susanoo, to offer it to heaven.
Therefore he sent Amanohukine no Kami, who was a fifth-generation descendant of Susanoo, to offer it to heaven.

sen.j: 此今所謂草薙劔矣
sen.e: This sword is what is now called Kusanagi no Tsurugi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「これが今、草薙剣といわれるものである。」
sen.e: This sword is what is now called Kusanagi no Tsurugi.
This sword is what is now called Kusanagi no Tsurugi.

sen.j: 初五十猛神 天降之時 多將樹種而下
sen.e: When Itakeru no Kami first descended from heaven, he brought a large number of tree seeds.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「はじめ五十猛神（いたけるのかみ）が天降られるときに、たくさんの樹の種をもって下られた。」
sen.e: When Itakeru no Kami first descended from heaven, he brought a large number of tree seeds.
When Itakeru no Kami first descended from heaven, he brought a large number of tree seeds.

sen.j: 然不殖韓地、盡以持歸
sen.e: However, he did not sow the soil in Korea with those seeds, and brought all of them back to Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「けれども韓地（からくに）に植えないで、すべて持ち帰った。」
sen.e: However, he did not sow them in Korea, and brought all of them back to Japan.
However, he did not sow them in Korea, and brought all of them back to Japan.

sen.j: 遂始自筑紫 凡大八洲國之内、莫不播殖而成青山焉
sen.e: He sowed the seeds all over the country of Oyashima (Great Myriad Islands, which is another name for Japan) starting with Tsukushi (Kyushu region), and he finally made the whole country covered by green mountains.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「筑紫からはじめて、大八洲の国の中に播きふやして、全部青山にしてしまわれた。」
sen.e: He sowed the seeds all over the country of Oyashima (Great Myriad Islands, which is another name for Japan) starting with Tsukushi (Kyushu), until finally the whole country was covered with green mountains.

He sowed the seeds all over the country of Oyashima (Great Myriad Islands, which is another name for Japan) starting with Tsukushi (Kyushu), until finally the whole country was covered with green mountains.

sen.j: 所以 稱五十猛命 爲有功之神
sen.e: Thus Itakeru no Mikoto is called Isaoshi no Kami (the 'deserving god') because of this story.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「このため五十猛命を名づけて、有功（いさおし）の神とする。」
sen.e: Thus Itakeru no Mikoto is called Isaoshi no Kami (the 'deserving god') because of this story.
Thus Itakeru no Mikoto is called Isaoshi no Kami (the 'deserving god') because of this story.

sen.j: 即紀伊國所坐大神是也
sen.e: He is the great god who is enshrined in Kii Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「紀伊国においでになる大神はこの神である。」
sen.e: He is the great god who is enshrined in Kii Province.
He is the great god who is enshrined in Kii Province.

sen.j: とあり天（『古事記』では高天原）を追放された素戔嗚尊とともに新羅曽尸茂梨に天降り、スサノオがこの地吾居ること欲さず（「乃興言曰 此地吾不欲居」）と言ったので、一緒に埴土船で渡って出雲国斐伊川上の鳥上峯に至ったとある。
sen.e: In summary, Isotakeru descended to Soshimori in Silla with Susanoo, who was banished from heaven (which is called Takaamahara in the "Kojiki"), and then they together moved to the place called Torikaminotake located at the upper reaches of Hi-kawa River in Izumo Province by a hani-bune (clay boat) because Susanoo said he did not want to stay in Soshimori.

In summary, Isotakeru descended to Soshimori in Silla with Susanoo, who was banished from heaven (which is called Takaamahara in the "Kojiki"), and then they together moved to the place called Torikaminotake located at the upper reaches of Hi-kawa River in Izumo Province by a hani-bune (clay boat) because Susanoo said he did not want to stay in Soshimori.

In summary, Isotakeru descended to Soshimori in Silla with Susanoo, who was banished from heaven (which is called Takaamahara in the "Kojiki"), and then they together moved to the place called Torikaminotake located at the upper reaches of Hii-kawa River in Izumo Province by a hani-bune (clay boat) because Susanoo said he did not want to stay in Soshimori.

sen.j: 五十猛神が天降る際に多くの樹木の種を持っていたが、新羅には植えずに全てを持ってきて、九州からはじめて八島に植えた。
sen.e: Isotakeru had many tree seeds when descending from heaven but he did not sow the seeds in Silla and brought all of them to Japan, and then he sowed the seeds throughout Yashima (Japan) starting from Kyushu region.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Isotakeru brought many tree seeds when descending from heaven but did not sow them in Silla, instead taking all of them to Japan, where, starting in Kyushu, he sowed them throughout Yashima (Japan).
Isotakeru brought many tree seeds when descending from heaven but did not sow them in Silla, instead taking all of them to Japan, where, starting in Kyushu, he sowed them throughout Yashima (Japan).

sen.j: そのため青山に被われる国となったという。
sen.e: It is said this is why Japan became a country covered by green mountains.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is said this is why Japan became a country covered with green mountains.
It is said this is why Japan became a country covered with green mountains.

sen.j: 同段の第五の一書では以下のとおりである。
sen.e: The fifth issho in the same section says as follows.
The fifth issho in the same section says as follows.
The fifth issho in the same section says as follows.

sen.j: 一書曰
sen.e: The issho says as follows.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「一書にいう。」
sen.e: The issho says as follows.
The issho says as follows.

sen.j: 素戔嗚尊曰 韓郷之嶋 是有金銀 若使吾兒所御之國 不有浮寶者 未是佳也
sen.e: Susanoo said 'There are gold and silver in islands of Korea. It would be not good if there is no ship in the country where my child rules.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「素戔嗚尊がいわれるのに、「韓郷（からくに）の島には金銀がある。もしわが子の治める国に、舟がなかったらよくないだろう」と。」
sen.e: Susanoo said 'There is gold and silver on the islands of Korea. It would not be good if there were no ships in the country where my child rules.'
Susanoo said 'There is gold and silver on the islands of Korea. It would not be good if there were no ships in the country where my child rules.'

sen.j: 乃拔鬚髯散之 即成杉
sen.e: He pulled out his mustache and beard and threw them, and then they became Japanese cedar trees.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「そこで髭を抜いて放つと杉の木になった。」
sen.e: He pulled out his mustache and beard and threw them, and they became Japanese cedar trees.
He pulled out his mustache and beard and threw them, and they became Japanese cedar trees.

sen.j: 又拔散胸毛 是成檜
sen.e: He pulled out his chest hairs and threw them, and then they became Japanese cypress trees.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「胸の毛を抜いて放つと桧になった。」
sen.e: He pulled out his chest hairs and threw them, and they became Japanese cypress trees.
He pulled out his chest hairs and threw them, and they became Japanese cypress trees.

sen.j: 尻毛是成柀
sen.e: The hairs of his buttocks became podocarp trees.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「尻の毛は槙の木になった」
sen.e: The hairs of his buttocks became yew pine trees.
sen.cmt: *Changed "podocarp" to "yew pine" though not sure if the Japanese name might not be better
sen.e: The hairs of his buttocks became podocarpus trees.
sen.cmt: yew pine→podocarpus yew はイチイ、マキは podocarpus となってます。[英辞郎 on the WEB]

sen.j: 眉毛是成櫲樟
sen.e: His eyebrows became camphor trees.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「眉の毛は樟（くすのき）になった。」
sen.e: His eyebrows became camphor trees.
His eyebrows became camphor trees.

sen.j: 已而定其當用 乃稱之曰 杉及櫲樟 此兩樹者 可以爲浮寶 檜可以爲瑞宮之材 柀可以爲顯見蒼生奥津棄戸將臥之具 夫須噉八十木種 皆能播生
sen.e: He designated the purpose of each tree and said 'Cedar and camphor trees, these two types of trees are good for making ships. Japanese cypress trees are good for building shrines. Podocarp trees are suitable for making coffins for people in this world. Let us sow a good many of tree seeds.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「そしてその用途をきめられて、いわれるのに、「杉と樟、この二つは舟をつくるのによい。桧は宮をつくる木によい。柀（槙）は現世の国民の寝棺を造るのによい。そのための沢山の木の種子を皆播こう」と。」
sen.e: He designated the purpose of each tree, saying, 'Cedar and camphor trees, these two types of trees are good for making ships. Japanese cypress trees are good for building shrines. Yew pine trees are suitable for making coffins for people in this world. Let us sow a good many tree seeds.'

He designated the purpose of each tree, saying, 'Cedar and camphor trees, these two types of trees are good for making ships. Japanese cypress trees are good for building shrines. Podocarpus trees are suitable for making coffins for people in this world. Let us sow a good many tree seeds.'

sen.j: 于時 素戔嗚尊之子 號曰五十猛命
sen.e: Susanoo's child is called Isotakeru no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「この素戔嗚尊の子を名づけて五十猛命（いそたけるのみこと）という。」
sen.e: Susanoo's child is called Isotakeru no Mikoto.
Susanoo's child is called Isotakeru no Mikoto.

sen.j: 妹大屋津姫命
sen.e: His younger sister is Oyatsuhime no Mikoto
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「妹の大屋津姫命（おおやつひめのみこと）。」
sen.e: His younger sister is Oyatsuhime no Mikoto
His younger sister is Oyatsuhime no Mikoto

sen.j: 次枛津姫命
sen.e: The next sister is Tsumatsuhime no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「次に枛津姫命（つまつひめのみこと）。」
sen.e: The next sister is Tsumatsuhime no Mikoto.
The next sister is Tsumatsuhime no Mikoto.

sen.j: 凡此三神 亦能分布木種
sen.e: These three gods worked hard to sow the seeds.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「この三柱の神がよく種子を播いた。」
sen.e: These three gods worked hard to sow the seeds.
These three gods worked hard to sow the seeds.

sen.j: 即奉渡於紀伊國也
sen.e: They are enshrined in Kii Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「紀伊国にお祀りしてある。」
sen.e: They are enshrined in Kii Province.
They are enshrined in Kii Province.

sen.j: 然後 素戔嗚尊 居熊成峯 而遂入於根國者矣
sen.e: Susanoo went to Kumanarinotake afterward and he finally entered the Nenokuni (underworld).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「その後に素戔嗚尊が熊成峯（くまなりのたけ）においでになって、ついに根の国にお入りになった。」
sen.e: Then Susanoo went to Mount Kumanarinotake and he finally entered Nenokuni (the underworld).
Then Susanoo went to Mount Kumanarinotake and he finally entered Nenokuni (the underworld).

sen.j: 棄戸 此云須多杯 柀 此云磨紀
sen.e: The term "棄戸" is pronounced as sutahe (coffin), and the term "柀" is pronounced as maki (podocarp).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「棄戸 はすたへといい、柀はまきと読む。」この文に限り参考図書に訳が掲載されていなかったため、翻訳者が現代語に訳しました。
sen.e: The term "棄戸" is pronounced "sutahe" (coffin), and the term "柀" is pronounced "maki" (yew pine).
The term "棄戸" is pronounced "sutahe" (coffin), and the term "柀" is pronounced "maki" (podocarpus).

sen.j: とあり素戔嗚尊が鬚髯からスギ、胸毛からヒノキ、尻毛から柀、眉毛など体毛を抜いて作った各種の樹木を、二柱の妹神（大屋津姫命と枛津姫命）とともに全国に植えたとある。
sen.e: In summary, this issho says Susanoo created various trees such as Japanese cedars from his mustaches and beards, Japanese cypresses from his chest hairs, podocarps from the hairs of his buttocks, and some other trees from his body hairs including his eyebrows, and Isotakeru and his two younger sister gods (Oyatsuhime and Tsumatsuhime) planted those trees throughout Japan.

In summary, this issho says Susanoo created various trees such as Japanese cedars from his mustache and beard, Japanese cypresses from his chest hairs, yew pines from the hairs of his buttocks, using his body hair including his eyebrows to make each kind of tree, and Isotakeru and his two younger sisters (Oyatsuhime and Tsumatsuhime) planted those trees throughout Japan.

In summary, this issho says Susanoo created various trees such as Japanese cedars from his mustache and beard, Japanese cypresses from his chest hairs, podocarpus from the hairs of his buttocks, using his body hair including his eyebrows to make each kind of tree, and Isotakeru and his two younger sisters (Oyatsuhime and Tsumatsuhime) planted those trees throughout Japan.

sen.j: どちらの一書でも、今は紀伊国に祀られているとしている。
sen.e: Both the issho versions say he is now enshrined in Kii Province.
Both the issho versions say he is now enshrined in Kii Province.
Both the issho versions say he is now enshrined in Kii Province.

sen.j: なお出雲の伝説ではスサノオらの上陸地点は出雲国に近い石見国・五十猛の海岸であるといわれ、ここから出雲国へと向かったとされている。
sen.e: According to the folklore of Izumo, the landing place of Susanoo and his company was the seacoast of Isotake, in Iwami Province, which was near to Izumo Province, and then they left that place for Izumo Province.
According to the folklore of Izumo, Susanoo and his children landed on coast of Isotake, in Iwami Province, which was near to Izumo Province, and then they left for Izumo Province.
According to the folklore of Izumo, Susanoo and his children landed on coast of Isotake, in Iwami Province, which was near to Izumo Province, and then they left for Izumo Province.

sen.j: 日本紀講筵の際提出された偽書とされる『先代旧事本紀』巻第四 地祇本紀の記述は以下のとおり。
sen.e: The following description is seen in the Chigihongi (the original record of earthly deity worship), the fourth volume of the "Sendai Kujihongi," which is thought to be a gisho (apocryphal book) which was submitted at a nihongi-koen (the studies and lectures on the Nihonshoki held in the Heian period).

The following description is seen in the Chigihongi (the True Record of the Earthly Deities) in the fourth volume of the "Sendai Kujihongi," which was submitted during a nihongi-koen (Heian period studies and lectures on the Nihonshoki) although it's authenticity is disputed.

The following description is seen in the Chigihongi (the True Record of the Earthly Deities) in the fourth volume of the "Sendai Kujihongi," which was submitted during a nihongi-koen (Heian period studies and lectures on the Nihonshoki) although it's authenticity is disputed.

sen.j: 素戔烏尊率其子 五十猛神 降到於新羅曾尸茂梨之處矣
sen.e: Susanoo descended to the place called Soshimori, in Silla, from heaven with his child named Isotakeru no Kami.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「素戔烏尊は子の五十猛神（いそたけるのかみ）を率いて、新羅の會尸茂梨（そしもり）と言う所に天降られた。」以下、先代旧事本紀の現代語訳は一部を除きhttp://www.asahi-net.or.jp/~xx8f-ishr/sendaikuji_mokuji.htmを参考といたしました。
sen.e: Susanoo descended from heaven to the place called Soshimori, in Silla, with his child named Isotakeru no Kami.
Susanoo descended from heaven to the place called Soshimori, in Silla, with his child named Isotakeru no Kami.

sen.j: 曾尸茂梨之處 纂疏新羅之地名也
sen.e: Soshimori is a name of a place in Silla.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「曾尸茂梨は新羅の地名である。」
sen.e: Soshimori is the name of a place in Silla.
Soshimori is the name of a place in Silla.

sen.j: 按倭名鈔高麗樂曲有蘇志摩利 疑其地風俗之歌曲乎
sen.e: Soshimari, written as 蘇志摩利 in Japanese, seen in the section of Goryeo music in the Wamyosho (a famous Heian-period Japanese dictionary) is the music reciting the customs of that place.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「倭名鈔の高麗樂曲にある蘇志摩利はその地の風俗を歌う曲である。」
sen.e: Soshimari, seen in the section on Goryeo music in the Wamyosho (a famous Heian-period Japanese dictionary) is a song that tells of the customs of that place.
sen.cmt: Deleted kanji as unecessaryPrepositionRevised for clarity
sen.e: Soshimari, seen in the section on Goryeo music in the Wamyosho (a famous Heian-period Japanese dictionary) is a song that tells of the customs of that place.

sen.j: 乃興言曰 此地吾不欲居
sen.e: After that, he said aloud 'I do not want to stay here.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「そして、声に出して「この地には居たく無い。」と言った。」
sen.e: After that, he said aloud, 'I do not want to stay here.'
After that, he said aloud, 'I do not want to stay here.'

sen.j: 遂以埴土作船 乘之東渡
sen.e: So he made a clay boat and traveled to the east by that boat.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「そして、埴土（はに）の船を作り、それに乗って東に渡った。」
sen.e: So he made a clay boat and traveled in it to the east.
So he made a clay boat and traveled in it to the east.

sen.j: 到于出雲國簸之河上與安藝國可愛之河上所在鳥上峰矣
sen.e: He reached the placed called Torikami where is in the upper reaches of Hi-kawa River in Izumo Province and in the upper reaches of Kaai-kawa River in Aki Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「出雲の国の簸（ひ）の河上と安藝（あき）の国の可愛（かあい）の河上とに有る鳥上に至った。」
sen.e: He reached the place called Torikami, which is in the upper reaches of the Hi-kawa River in Izumo Province and the upper reaches of the Kaai-kawa River in Aki Province.
He reached the place called Torikami, which is in the upper reaches of the Hi-kawa River in Izumo Province and the upper reaches of the Kaai-kawa River in Aki Province.

sen.j: （ヤマタノオロチ退治省略）
sen.e: (The story of the Yamatanoorochi defeat omitted)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: (Story of Yamatanoorochi's defeat omitted)
(Story of Yamatanoorochi's defeat omitted)

sen.j: 素戔烏尊居熊成峰而遂入於根國矣
sen.e: Susanoo entered the Nenokuni from Kumanasunomine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「素戔烏尊は熊成峯（くまなすのみね）で根国（ねのくに）に入られた。」
sen.e: Susanoo entered Nenokuni from Mount Kumanasunomine.
Susanoo entered Nenokuni from Mount Kumanasunomine.

sen.j: 兒 五十猛神天降之時 多將八十樹種須噉子樹種而不殖韓地 盡以持歸
sen.e: His child called Isotakeru no Kami brought seeds of various types of trees and crops when he descended from heaven, but he brought them back to Japan without sowing them in Korea.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「子の五十猛神（いそたけるのかみ）が天下られる時に多くの種類の木の種や作物の種を持ってきたが韓地（からのち）に蒔かず儘もって還ってきた。」
sen.e: His child, called Isotakeru no Kami, brought seeds of various types of trees and crops when he descended from heaven, but he brought them back to Japan without sowing them in Korea.
His child, called Isotakeru no Kami, brought seeds of various types of trees and crops when he descended from heaven, but he brought them back to Japan without sowing them in Korea.

sen.j: 遂始自筑紫 於大八洲之内 莫不殖播而成青山矣
sen.e: He eventually started to sow the seeds in Tsukushi and then spread them all over the country of Oyashima to make the country full of green mountains.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「遂に筑紫から始めて大八州の国内に撒き植え青山とされた。」
sen.e: He eventually started to sow the seeds in Tsukushi and then spread them all over the country of Oyashima, filling the country with green mountains.
He eventually started to sow the seeds in Tsukushi and then spread them all over the country of Oyashima, filling the country with green mountains.

sen.j: 所謂五十猛命 為有功之神
sen.e: Isotakeru no Mikoto has a great achievement.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「五十猛命は功績の有る神である。」
sen.e: Isotakeru no Mikoto achieved great things.
Isotakeru no Mikoto achieved great things.

sen.j: 則紀伊國所坐大神是也
sen.e: He is a great god who is enshrined in Kii Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「紀伊の国に座す大神である。」
sen.e: He is a great god who is enshrined in Kii Province.
He is a great god who is enshrined in Kii Province.

sen.j: 一説曰 素戔烏尊之子 號曰 五十猛命 妹 大屋姫命 次 抓津姫命
sen.e: According to another story, Susanoo had three child gods, the child named Isotakeru no Mikoto, his younger sister named Oyahime no Mikoto, and the youngest sister named Tsumatsuhime no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「一説に素戔烏尊の子で名を五十猛命と言い、妹は大屋姫命（おおやひめのみこと）、次の妹が抓津姫命（つまつひめのみこと）の三神である。」
sen.e: According to another story, Susanoo had three child gods, the child named Isotakeru no Mikoto, his younger sister, named Oyahime no Mikoto, and the youngest sister, named Tsumatsuhime no Mikoto.
According to another story, Susanoo had three child gods, the child named Isotakeru no Mikoto, his younger sister, named Oyahime no Mikoto, and the youngest sister, named Tsumatsuhime no Mikoto.

sen.j: 凡三神 亦能分布八十木種 則奉渡於紀伊國
sen.e: Also, they sowed many seeds very hard and moved to Kii Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「また、良く多くの種子を撒き植えられ、紀伊の国に渡し奉る。」
sen.e: Also, they worked hard sowing many seeds and moved to Kii Province.
Also, they worked hard sowing many seeds and moved to Kii Province.

sen.j: 及此國所祭之神是也
sen.e: In other words, they are the gods who are enshrined in this province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「すなわち、この国に祭られている神である。」
sen.e: In other words, they are the gods who are enshrined in this province.
In other words, they are the gods who are enshrined in this province.

sen.j: 素戔烏尊
sen.e: Susanoo
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「素戔烏尊」
sen.e: Susanoo
Susanoo

sen.j: 此尊與天照太神共誓約（中略）次 五十猛命 亦云 大屋彦神 次 大屋姫神 次 抓津姫神
sen.e: This mikoto (a god) swear with Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess)...and the god named Isotakeru no Kami (also known as Oyahiko no Kami), followed by Oyahime no Kami and Tsumatsuhime no Kami.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「この尊は天照大神と共に誓約を行い（中略）次に五十猛神（いそたけるのかみ）亦の名を大屋彦神（おおやひこのかみ）と言い、次に大屋姫神（おおやひめのかみ）次に抓津姫神（つまつひめのかみ）」
sen.e: This mikoto (god) swears with Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess)...and the god named Isotakeru no Kami, also known as Oyahiko no Kami, followed by Oyahime no Kami and Tsumatsuhime no Kami.
This mikoto (god) swears with Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess)...and the god named Isotakeru no Kami, also known as Oyahiko no Kami, followed by Oyahime no Kami and Tsumatsuhime no Kami.

sen.j: 已上三柱 並坐 紀伊國
sen.e: These three gods are in Kii Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「これらの三神は紀伊の国に居られる。」
sen.e: These three gods are in Kii Province.
These three gods are in Kii Province.

sen.j: 則紀伊國造齋祠神也
sen.e: In other words, they are gods who are enshrined by Kiinokuni no miyatsuko (a provincial governor in Kii Province).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「紀伊国造の斎祭る神である。」
sen.e: In other words, they are gods who are enshrined by Kiinokuni no miyatsuko (the governor in Kii Province).
In other words, they are gods who are enshrined by Kiinokuni no miyatsuko (the governor in Kii Province).
